prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Pallas Band 6 Continuum Brightness Temperature Images
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 continuum brightness temperature images of main-belt asteroid Pallas.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
The relative constraints for these observations are determined by the asteroid's rotation period. Repeat visits can be scheduled at greater delays when the asteroid's rotation phase is appropriate.
Our total time estimate is based on the small amount of time required on source and the presence of bright calibrator sources that will require far less time than the default estimate.

The relative constraints for these observations are determined by the asteroid's rotation period. Repeat visits can be scheduled at greater delays when the asteroid's rotation phase is appropriate.
Our total time estimate is based on the small amount of time required on source and the presence of bright calibrator sources that will require far less time than the default estimate.

The relative constraints for these observations are determined by the asteroid's rotation period. Repeat visits can be scheduled at greater delays when the asteroid's rotation phase is appropriate.
Our total time estimate is based on the small amount of time required on source and the presence of bright calibrator sources that will require far less time than the default estimate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: These are continuum observations, and do not require high spectral resolution.
To obtain the highest possible angular resolution.
To construct a model of the asteroid's shape and spin state and to see diurnal temperature variations, we must observe it over a wide range of rotation phases.
The asteroid is a compact object, which requires the highest possible angular resolution to resolve but is only a few tenths of an arcsecond across.

The asteroid has peak brightness temperature of ~250 K; but other parts of its surface are much colder. We have selected integration time to have SNR >> 10 on even the coldest parts of the surface to determine the asteroid's dimensions to much better than the synthesized beam width.
Based on the small amount of time on-source and the presence of bright calibrators.
To insure selection of bright calibrators to minimize total observation time.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent ALMA observations of the asteroid 3 Juno have demonstrated the array's capability to image large main-belt asteroids. We propose more extensive main-belt asteroid imaging, studying six objects that have previously been observed optically and with radar, and in one case by a spacecraft flyby. ALMA imaging would provide shape, spin-state, and density information and map large-scale surface variations, with implications for the history of the asteroid belt
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Dept of Natural Sciences, University of Maine at Farmington
Department of Physics & Astronomy, Pittsburgh, University of
